gui

Class BasicRobotTest

  • java.lang.Object
    • gui.BasicRobotTest

  • public class BasicRobotTest
extends java.lang.Object
    BasicRobotTest provides a mix of black-box and white-box testing of the BasicRobot class. It maintains a robot field and is aware that this robot is a BasicRobot. It also instantiates instances of Floorplan, Distance, and Maze classes for the robot to navigate, which serves as the basis of testing. Additional testing via in-line assert statements are located in BasicRobot.
    Author:
    Elijah Mas

      • instantiateApplication

        private void instantiateApplication(int level,
                                    boolean perfect)
        Build a new maze at a given level to be used for testing and establish the controller that will operate on it. Maze generation is random, rooms are permissible by way of the perfect parameter.
        Parameters:
        level - level of the maze to be generated
        perfect - whether or not the maze should be perfect

      • buildNewMaze

        private void buildNewMaze(int level,
                          boolean perfect)
        Build a new maze at a given level to be used for testing and establish the controller that will operate on it. Also create a RobotOperationTracker to compute a path out of this maze for testing purposes.
        Parameters:
        level - level of the maze to be generated
        perfect - whether or not the maze should be perfect

      • resetFields

        private void resetFields()
        Cleanup method: sets values to null so that the test class has no memory of data from the previous maze.

      • resetState

        private void resetState()
        Set the control and robot fields to null, allowing a new controller and robot to be established. Used to allow a series of tests to be run on a maze with a fresh controller/robot pair for each test.

      • setController

        Using the current maze field, set a controller to start a playing state from this maze.
        Parameters:
        justEnoughEnergy - whether or not to leave the robot just enough energy to exit the maze

        Parameters:

      • tests

        @ParameterizedTest
 @ValueSource(ints={0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7})
public void tests(int level)

        Automate the testing of mazes over some number of trials.

        Mazes are tested from levels 0-7; at each level, two mazes are randomly generated: one perfect, one imperfect, and each is subjected to the same test suite, encapsulated in the testMaze method.

        Thus if trials=10, ((7-0)+1)*2+10 = 160 mazes are tested. On my computer, time ratio is ~150-160 seconds / 10 trials.

        The reason all tests are combined into one main method instead of labeling each method as a @Test method is because the above permutation of test case (8 levels × 2 perfect values × 10 trials) is difficult to achieve the latter way.

      • testMaze

        private void testMaze(int level,
                      boolean perfect)
        Run the suite of tests to be conducted on each maze.
        Parameters:
        level - level of the maze
        perfect - whether or not the maze should be perfect

        Parameters:
        d -
        runOutOfEnergyFirst - whether or not the robot should run out of energy before crashing

      • testBadJump

        private void testBadJump(boolean runOutOfEnergyFirst)
        Test that a bad jump (an attempt to jump outside a maze) fails as expected. There is also the option to have the robot run out of energy before attempting the bad jump, in which case the robot should stop first.
        Parameters:
        runOutOfEnergyFirst - whether to have the robot run out of energy before attempting the jump

      • jumpPossible

        private boolean jumpPossible(Robot.Direction d)
        Tell whether a jump is possible in a given direction. True if all conditions are met:
        • sufficient energy
        • wall immediately in front
        • not jumping out of maze
        Parameters:
        d - a Robot.Direction value
        Returns:
        whether a jump is possible towards d

      • walkToExit

        private float walkToExit(boolean tryInterrupt)
        Using the operations list provided by tracker, walk the robot to the exit cell of the maze. Along the way tests are performed to ensure that the robot and the Controller concur on the current position and direction. Also test that at the end of this sequence, the robot is facing the exit, which is part of the design specification of RobotOperationTracker.
        Parameters:
        tryInterrupt - whether or not to try interrupting the walk process, used when testing jump functionality

      • walkToExitWithDisabledSensors

        private void walkToExitWithDisabledSensors()
        Call walkToExitWithDisabledSensors(boolean) for input values of true and false.

      • walkToExitWithDisabledSensors

        private void walkToExitWithDisabledSensors(boolean disableForwardBackward)
        Walk through the maze and exit, but disable certain sensors and check that things behave as expected. The side sensors are always disabled for this method; the front and back sensors can be disabled, and nothing should change.
        Parameters:
        disableForwardBackward - whether or not to disable front and back sensors

      • assertOutsideMaze

        private void assertOutsideMaze()
        Assert that after leaving a maze, the robot recognizes it is outside, and the Controller has switched to the winning state. Called when the robot has left a maze.

      • moveOutExitByJump

        private void moveOutExitByJump()
        From the exit cell, exit the maze by attempting a jump. The robot is programmed to substitute a move operation for a jump if it recognizes that there is no wall directly in front of it. So this should perform a move operation under the hood, thus successfully exiting the maze.

      • moveOutExit

        private void moveOutExit()
        From the exit cell, leave the maze by a move operation, and assert that the robot has indeed left the maze.

      • assertEnergyDepleted

        private void assertEnergyDepleted()
        Test that the robot has run out of energy and the game has ended.

      • testAround

        private void testAround()
        Test the special case where the robot receives a command to turn around and has enough energy for only one rotation.

      • testInsufficientEnergy_RotateStopsRobot

        private void testInsufficientEnergy_RotateStopsRobot()
        Call #testInsufficientEnergy_RotateStopsRobot(Turn) for each Robot.Turn value, then call testAround().

      • testInsufficientEnergy_RotateStopsRobot

        private void testInsufficientEnergy_RotateStopsRobot(Robot.Turn t)
        Test that the robot does not rotate if it has insufficient energy for a single rotation.
        Parameters:
        t - Robot.Turn value for BasicRobot.rotate

      • testInsufficientEnergy_MoveStopsRobot

        private void testInsufficientEnergy_MoveStopsRobot()
        Test whether a robot stops as expected when it tries to move without having enough energy.

      • testInsufficientEnergy_JumpStopsRobot

        private void testInsufficientEnergy_JumpStopsRobot()
        Call testInsufficientEnergy_JumpStopsRobot(boolean) with input values true and false.

      • testInsufficientEnergy_JumpStopsRobot

        private void testInsufficientEnergy_JumpStopsRobot(boolean withDistanceEnergy)
        Test whether a robot stops after attempting a jump due to insufficient energy. The robot either has too little energy to jump, or enough energy to jump but not enough energy to sense distances after the jump.
        Parameters:
        withDistanceEnergy - if true, the robot has energy to jump, but not enough to sense distances afterwards

      • testJumps

        private void testJumps()
        Test that a robot can jump over a wall, turn around, and jump over the same wall without errors. Calls the testJump() method to perform tests.

      • testJump

        private void testJump()
        Test that a robot completes a jump without error.

      • getRobotPosition

        private int[] getRobotPosition()
        wrapper around Robot.getCurrentPosition() that handles exception throw
        Returns:
        position if no exception, otherwise null

      • assertEqualOrientation

        private void assertEqualOrientation()
        Assert that the robot and controller agree on position and direction.

      • assertExitSight

        private void assertExitSight()
        Assert that the method Robot.canSeeThroughTheExitIntoEternity(Direction) works as expected. When the method return true, the robot must be in at least the same row or column as the exit, and there must be no walls in the direction to the exit. When it returns false for a given direction, there must be a wall in the given direction at some distance.

      • assertOrientation

        private void assertOrientation()
        Assert that the robot and controller have equal orientation (call the assertEqualOrientation() method), and verify that Robot.canSeeThroughTheExitIntoEternity(Direction) is functioning properly by calling assertExitSight().

      • getController

        private Controller getController(boolean perfect,
                                 boolean deterministic,
                                 int level)
        Sets things in order for a maze to be generated. OrderStub, Controller, and MazeBuilder instances receive the parameters required to initialize the maze. Ensures that the maze is finished generating before tests are performed.
        Parameters:
        perfect - boolean:{maze is perfect}
        deterministic - boolean:{maze is generated deterministically}
        level - level of the maze
        Returns:
        the generated Maze instance

      • mathTest

        public void mathTest()
        Test methods from MazeMath. Going forward I might move this into a new test class.

      • testExtendedList

        public void testExtendedList()
        Test methods from ExtendedList. Going forward I might move this into a new test class.
